s1: This course aims to provide students with sufficient knowledge of the basic principles of software project management that they may support a project manager to carry out the project administrative functions of a program office, understand leadership and management within the context of an agile project development team, and understand the context in which project management is conducted.
s2: The course also introduces students to standard productivity tools for software development that will be used throughout the course and remainder of the computer science degree.

s1: Many of the skills gained are of use outside formal project management environments.
s2: The course also introduces students to standard productivity tools for software development that will be used throughout the course and remainder of the computer science degree.

s1: Leadership,  Management, Professionalism, Ethics and Teamwork
s2: Describe, understand and evolve programs, via documentation, testing, and debugging.

s1: Identify and describe the impact  of business  context on a software development project, including an understanding of the role professional ethics plays in the conduct of a successful project.
s2: It introduces students to the field of computer science as a discipline for solving problems through computation and provides the foundation for more advanced courses on programming and software development.

s1: Evaluate the features of traditional and agile approaches to managing software development to decide an appropriate project management approach for a project in a business context.
s2: Describe and apply alternative computational paradigms to simple problems.

s1: Demonstrate key project management skills such as scope determination; task decomposition; effort estimation, schedule creation and tracking; progress reporting; and management of risk and quality
s2: Students also gain exposure to structural induction and proof, introduction to asymptotic analysis of basic data structures, abstract data types, modules, laziness, and streams.

s1: Employ research, critical thinking and reflection to formulate and communicate an argument concerning project management concepts.
s2: Describe and apply alternative computational paradigms to simple problems.

s1: Demonstrate teamwork and collaboration skills, and an understanding of the difference between leadership and management.
s2: It introduces students to the field of computer science as a discipline for solving problems through computation and provides the foundation for more advanced courses on programming and software development.
